result.first_aid_text:
* If it is practical to do so apply firm pressure to the wound with a clean cloth.
* Do not try to feed your cat until you have checked with your vet practice that it is ok to do so.
* Do not allow your cat to lick at or scratch the wound.
* Try to keep your cat quiet and calm.
result.problem_text:
* Rapid blood loss puts your cat in immediate danger. Emergency treatment by a vet is required to stop the bleeding, to correct the effects on the circulation and to investigate and treat the underlying cause (the wound).
* Severe blood loss can lead to shock, collapse, organ damage and death. Even apparently minor wounds can lead to significant blood loss over time, if untreated.
* Once the bleeding has stopped, the clot will be fragile and the wound can reopen and bleed again, although this is usually less severe.

risk_category.desc: *You need to contact your vet immediately*
risk_category.name: Urgent
risk_category.text_1:
* Your vet may give you telephone advice or may ask to see you.
* Always telephone the vets before going to the practice. The vet may need to give you special instructions or an appointment time.
* Take care. When pets are injured or ill they may accidentally bite or scratch.

result.travel_advice_text: * Cats should be transported in appropriate, secure carrying boxes.

options.text: Blood is trickling, streaming or pulsing out

question.text: How much blood is coming out?
